content.body: Then why did you state something to that effect?
i didn't

Obviously too subtle.  ^_^

my point is that if the user clears cookies, the user agent should suggest to the user that if the goal is to prevent user tracking, that clearing the local storage, session storage, web database, flash storage, cache, and other such mechanisms is necessary to ensure the user's privacy
how this happens is up to the ua
whether it happens by just treating them all the same, or by having a complicated six-page explanation in a modal dialog, is up to the UI designer
what does the "I've read the changes!" button do?
on the tracker
What you actually *said* was: "we have to make sure that clearing one clears the other".
You did *not* say "We have to give users the option to clear both at once."
clearing both at once automatically would be ideal, imho, yes
Your words imply that it's a requirement that they are cleared together, rather than an option.
but what _i_ want isn't relevant here
as it's not what the spec requires
Indeed.  As it is, browsers can *choose* to make LocalStorage completely ephemeral, so we can't rely on it.
they can also "choose" to make every click result in the computer exploding, but that doesn't mean we can't use <a href="">.
Sure, but no one's suggesting that behavior is vitally important for the user's privacy. ("No one can violate your privacy if the computer's blown up!")
On the other hand, *you* are suggesting precisely that wrt LocalStorage.

<span> is fine if used with lang="" or dir="" or the like.

hmm, ok. Is that because they do that weird thing where they just prefix the namespace URI to the localname?
jgraham: I don't remember anyone suggesting "must not", just "does not have to (but can if you've got a suitable API; it doesn't matter as long as you get the same result from the same syntax)"
Philip`: "The original objection was that different processing is required for

As far as I can tell the only way to make sense of that would be to forbid using namespace aware processors
jgraham: (Some) namespace aware processors let you iterate through the list of attributes and pull out xmlns:*
Lachy: the RDFa TF is programming with namespace-unaware tools (Mark Birbeck: IE, Shane: the perl lib, Ivan Herman: Python minidom)
e.g. web browser DOMs do
jgraham: so they still satisfy that requirement
Lachy: whereas people here are programming with libraries whose authors have drank the Infoset kool aid

we should see the light and stop caring about namespaces and namespace-aware APIs

Dashiva: Presumably because it scores brownie points with TAG
Dashiva: Because it doesn't cause trouble
(when you use namespace-unaware APIs)
jgraham: Nice order of constituencies :)
and because it can reuse the normal xmlns processing model, rather than having to define its own that's almost identical but slightly different
Philip`: Neither does a mechanism that doesn't cause trouble when you _do_ use namespace aware APIs
(and thus avoid reinventing wheels)
processing model?
You mean doing a string split on :?
isn't sure what Philip` means by "xmlns processing model" but Mark has explicitly stated that authors are expected to keep track of prefixes at the application level, independent of the ns machanisms

jgraham: I just mean the definition of what namespace bindings are in scope at a particular element, which is (I'd hope) defined in the Namespaces spec and so RDFa just references that instead of redefining it (even if practical implementations will reimplement it)
Philip`: It seems highly misleading to imply that processing happens per xmlns when in fact you are actually required to ignore xmlns and do your own prefix binding processing
jgraham: You're not required to ignore it, you could do it with lookupNamespaceURI if you wanted
and the result is equivalent to the normal proper xmlns processing
(though it's sufficient (but not necessary) to just have an API that exposes a list of namespace-unaware attributes per element)
Dashiva: it's politically expedient in the W3C to use namespace-looking syntax. It gets you an applause even if you break the XML architecture all over.

hsivonen, it's primary usecase seems to have shifted. <sidebar> was introduced to address the common case of <div id="sidebar">, then adjusted to also address callouts as being tangentially related content
and then renamed to <aside> based on that
FWIW <header> <footer> <content> and <sidebar> make sense as "structural" elements to me. <aside> or <callout> seems more like <section>
More specifically, I would expect <sidebar><nav></nav></sidebar> to increment the heading depth by 1 whereas I would expect <aside><nav> to increment the heading depth by 2
if we make <aside> inappropriate for page sidebars, then I would change it so that it's no longer a sectioning element
and I would expect <sidebar> to be a sectioning element.

Friends

...

and you also need to make sure you explicitly close

elements with

if it precedes one of the new sectioning elements like
but their presence in the DOM won't inherently break things

Lachy: My point is that trying to draw semantic distinctions between header/footer/aside (used as website structure) doesn't do any good.  If you can put some item in one of those locations, it's almost guaranteed to be attested in the other two across the web as well.
So, semantically, header/footer/aside as *website structure* are very nearly the same (header being a slight exception, as it nearly always contains the site header).
header/footer/aside used in an article carry very real and distinctly different meanings, of course.  These are currently expressed in the spec.
and as I tried to point out on the list, you're placing too much significance on the content alone, and ignoring the structural and contextual meanings conveyed by each

it's not introductory content, it doesn't belong there

it's not just visual consideration. It's structural and semantic

Those four are placed in the heading area for purely visual reasons.
